questions.text: All of the following open into middle meatus except:
questions.solution:
• Sphenoid sinus drains into sphenoethmoidal recess.
  • Maxillary, frontal sinuses and anterior ethmoid sinuses drain into middle meatus
  • Posterior ethmoid air cells drain into superior meatus

questions.text:
False about Caldwell-Luc operation:
a. Infraorbital nerve damage may occur as complication
b. Opening of maxillary antrum through gingivobuccal incision
c. Used for the treatment of chronic maxillary sinusitis & for obtaining biopsy for antral malignancy
d. Sublabial approach leading to opening of mandibular antrum may be done under local anaesthesia with nerve block
questions.solution:
Caldwell-Luc Operation (Anterior Antrostomy):

Definition:

  • The Caldwell-Luc operation involves opening the maxillary antrum through the canine fossa using a sublabial approach.
  • It's also known as anterior antrostomy as it provides access to the maxillary sinus through the anterior wall.

Indications:

  1. Chronic Maxillary Sinusitis: When there are irreversible changes in sinus mucosa.
  2. Suspected Neoplasm: To biopsy suspected tumors in the antrum.
  3. Maxillary Artery Ligation: Approaching the pterygopalatine fossa for ligation of the maxillary artery.

Operational Procedure:

  1. Incision: A horizontal incision is made below the gingivolabial sulcus, from lateral incisor to second molar.
  2. Mucoperiosteal Flap: The mucoperiosteal flap is then raised from the canine fossa to the infraorbital nerve, ensuring nerve protection.

Objective:

  • The goal is to provide access to the maxillary sinus through the canine fossa for various procedures mentioned.

Anesthesia

General Anesthesia with Cuffed Endotracheal Tube and Pharyngeal Pack:

  • The procedure is performed under general anesthesia.
  • A cuffed endotracheal tube is inserted into the trachea to secure the airway and facilitate mechanical ventilation during surgery.
  • A pharyngeal pack is used to minimize the risk of blood or fluids entering the throat or trachea.

questions.text: 16 year old patient presents with pain over the cheek. Patient also complains of nasal discharge and nasal blockage. Examination reveals oedema of lower eyelids and purulent discharge in middle meatus. Involvement of which of the following para-nasal sinus is suspected?
questions.solution:
This is a case of maxillary sinusitis. Mucoid or mucopurulent discharge in middle meatus is pathognomic of maxillary sinusitis.

Other symptoms include constitutional symptoms , headache, postnasal drip, pain - over the cheek, upper jaw, but may be referred to the gums or teeth.

Lower eyelid edema and mucosal edema can also be seen.

questions.text: Kiesselbach's plexus in Little's area of septum gets contribution from all these arteries except-
questions.solution:
Kiesselbach's plexus-

  • Anastomosis of anterior ethmoidal, septal branch of superior labial, septal branch of sphenopalatine and the greater palatine

It lies in Little's area on the anteroinferior part of nasal septum just above the vestibule.

It is the most common site of epistaxis in children and young adults

questions.text: A teenager was brought to the hospital by her mother for the evaluation of delay in onset of puberty. While taking the history of the patient, she says that she has always had a very poor sense of smell. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Kallmann syndrome.

  • Anosmia
  • Congenital hypogonadism leading to delay in puberty

questions.text: A 6 year old child presented to ENT OPD. The mother is complaining that the child is suffering from hearing loss. The Otoscopy picture is given in the image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The otoscopy picture depicts a retracted tympanic membrane with a dull appearance and a fluid-filled middle ear space behind it. This clinical presentation is indicative of Otitis Media with Effusion (OME), also known as "glue ear". OME occurs when fluid accumulates in the middle ear without acute infection. It is common in young children and can lead to temporary hearing loss due to the restriction of tympanic membrane movement and interference with sound transmission to the inner ear.

Other options:

B. Pneumo Tympanum - This condition refers to the presence of air in the middle ear cavity, but it is not consistent with the otoscopy image showing fluid-filled middle ear space.

C. Myringitis Bullosa - Myringitis Bullosa is characterized by the formation of bullae or blisters on the tympanic membrane. The image does not show any bullae or blisters

D. Acute Suppurative Otitis Media - Acute Suppurative Otitis Media is characterized by the presence of pus in the middle ear due to a bacterial infection. The image does not show signs of active infection with pus formation.

questions.text: Partial closure of nasal orifice done in which condition?
questions.solution:
Partial closure of the nasal orifice is performed in cases of atrophic rhinitis. Atrophic rhinitis is a condition characterized by the thinning and wasting away of the nasal mucosa, leading to crusting, dryness, and foul-smelling nasal discharge. Partial closure aims to improve symptoms and airflow through the nose.

Other options:

  • Chronic fungal aspergillosis: This is a chronic infection of the nose and sinuses caused by the fungus Aspergillus. It can cause nasal obstruction, but it is not typically associated with partial closure of the nasal orifices.
  • Vasomotor rhinitis: This is a condition in which the blood vessels in the nose become dilated, causing congestion. It can cause nasal obstruction, but it is not typically associated with partial closure of the nasal orifices.
  • Fungal mucormycosis: This is a serious infection of the nose and sinuses caused by the fungus Mucor. It can cause nasal obstruction, but it is not typically associated with partial closure of the nasal orifices.

questions.text: Which of the following tests cannot be used to assess nasal mucociliary clearance?
questions.solution:
Nasal mucociliary clearance refers to the process by which mucus and debris are cleared from the nasal passages through the action of cilia on the nasal epithelium. Several tests can be used to assess nasal mucociliary clearance, but electron microscopy is not one of them.

These are valid methods to assess nasal mucociliary clearance:

A. Saccharine Test: This is a simple test in which a small amount of saccharine is placed in the nostril, and the time it takes for the patient to perceive a sweet taste in the mouth is measured. The movement of saccharine through the nasal passages indicates mucociliary clearance.

C. Charcoal powder method: In this test, charcoal particles are insufflated into the nasal cavity, and the time it takes for the patient to expectorate the particles is measured. The clearance of charcoal particles indicates mucociliary clearance.

D. Scintigraphy: Radioactive particles are used in this test to assess the movement of mucus through the nasal passages and the clearance of radioactive particles indicates mucociliary clearance.

Electron microscopy is not a method used for assessing nasal mucociliary clearance. Instead, it is a microscopic technique used to study the ultrastructure of cilia and mucociliary function in certain research settings

questions.text: Which procedure is shown in the following figure
questions.solution:
The figure shows the performance of an anterior ethmoidal block. This procedure involves injecting a local anesthetic agent into the anterior ethmoidal nerve to provide anesthesia and pain relief during specific nasal surgeries or interventions.

Other options are:

  • Frontal sinus trephination is a procedure that is performed to drain the frontal sinus. It involves making a small hole in the frontal bone to access the sinus. This procedure is not performed on the ethmoid sinuses.
  • Checking nasolacrimal duct patency ROW is a procedure that is performed to assess the patency of the nasolacrimal duct. It involves inserting a probe into the nasolacrimal duct to see if it is blocked. This procedure is not performed on the ethmoid sinuses.
  • Inferior orbital block is a nerve block that is performed to numb the inferior orbital nerve. This nerve supplies the lower eyelid, cheek, and upper lip. This procedure is not performed on the ethmoid sinuses.

questions.text: Consider the following findings:
questions.solution:
In this case:

  • Rinne's test is positive in both ears -> Indicates a normal test or bilateral SNHL
  • Weber's is lateralised to left -> Indicates left ear has better hearing
  • ABC is decreased in both ears -> Bilateral SNHL

So this is a case of bilateral sensorineural hearing loss(Right > Left ear).

questions.text: What type of tympanogram is given in the picture?
questions.solution: Type C curve is on the negative pressure side and is seen in Eustachian tube blockage. Type B is Flat Tympanogram seen in glue ear or perforated ear drum.

questions.text: A child is born with deformed pinna as seen below. What is the name of this deformity?
questions.solution:
Bat Ear :

If anti helix is absent, it is called BAT EAR.

  • Cosmetic surgery of pinna called Otoplasty

Ideal age of otoplasty ≥ 6 yrs

TM touching promontory, does not move on seigelistaion
TM touching promontory but moves on Seigelisation

questions.text: Grade 3 Sade classification describing retraction of pars tensa includes
questions.solution: Sade Classification of Retraction of Pars Tensa

questions.text: Identify the incision shown the given image?
questions.solution: Rosen's endomeatal incision is used for stapes surgery in Otosclerosis.

choices.text: Cell balls of Zellballen on histopathology

questions.text: All are clinically applicable statements to glomus Jugulare except
questions.solution:
Treatment of Glomus Jugulare:

Treatment-Rx Of choice is surgery. Gamma knife therapy is 2nd option.

On histopathology it appear as cell balls of Zellballen.

questions.text: The given investigation in the picture checks the function of which structure of inner ear?
questions.solution:
The given picture shows VEMP(Vestibular Evoked Myogenic Potential):

In VEMP, we stimulate the saccule with sound and we record the contractions of Sternocleidomastoid muscle(Vestibulocollic reflex). This test checks the inferior vestibular division of 8th nerve as saccule is supplied by this nerve.

questions.text: Vestibular evoked myogenic potential(VEMP) tests which nerve
questions.solution:
VEMP (VESTIBULAR EVOKED MYOGENIC POTENTIAL)

In this test we stimulate the Saccule with loud sound and we record the electrical activity of sternocleidomastoid muscle.

  • VEMP is a test to detect function of
    • Saccule
    • Inferior vestibular division of 8th Nerve.
  • This nerve supplies to Saccule.

Uses of VEMP-

  1. Acoustic neuroma.
  2. Superior semicircular canal dehiscence.
  3. Meniere's disease.

questions.text: "Tullio's phenomenon" consists of dizziness induced by sound occurs in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Tullio's phenomenon: Patients can get vertigo on hearing loud sounds.

It is seen in

1.Menieres Disease

2.Perilymph fistula

3.Superior semicircular canal dehiscence.

Roll Over Phenomenon is positive in case of acoustic neuroma.

questions.text: One of the following is not a common feature of Vestibular schwannoma
questions.solution:
• Facial palsy occurs when the motor fibres of CN VII are involved.
  • Motor fibres are more resistant and are affected late. So facial palsy would not be a common feature of vestibular schwannoma.
  • Sensory fibresof CN VII are affected early - cause Hitzelberger sign.

questions.text: In a patient of facial nerve injury, Schirmer's test shows decreased lacrimation, taste sensation is impaired and stapedial reflex is absent. Where is the level of injury?
questions.solution:
Topodiagnostic Tests:

  1. Schirmer's Test - Reduced lacrimation - lesion proximal to geniculate ganglion(first genu)
  2. Stapedial Reflex - Lost in lesions above Nerve. to Stapedius(second genu)
  3. Taste test - Impairment of taste means lesion above chorda tympani origin

In this question,

  • Lacrimation - absentl
  • Stapedial reflex - Abscent
  • Taste sensation - Impaired

So the level of lesion is above the first genu, in the labyrinthine segment.

choices.text: Recovery of facial nerve is nearly universal
Site of viral activation is geniculate ganglion

questions.text: Which is not true about Ramsay Hunt syndrome
questions.solution:
RAMSAY HUNT SYNDROME-

  • Also known as Herpes zoster oticus.
  • It is due to reactivation of Varicella zoster virus in Geniculate ganglion of facial Nerve

Clinical features

  1. Painful vesicle in external ear.
  2. 7th nerve- Lower motor neuron facial palsy (ipsilateral)
  • Treatment- Acyclovir and steroid therapy.
  • Recovery is seen in 50% patients only.

choices.text: Malleus incus and stapes superstructure are absent

questions.text: Partial ossicular replacement prostheis is used when

A 3 year old child while playing with toys suddenly developed swallowing difficulty and is excessively crying. The parents rushed the child to emergency where the X- ray Chest was conducted. The X Ray image is shown in the given picture. What is the best management of this patinet?
questions.solution:
INDICATIONS Diagnostic

  1. To investigate cause for dysphagia, e.g. cancer oesophagus, cardiac achalasia, strictures, oesophagitis, diverticulae, etc.
  2. To find cause for retrosternal burning, g. reflux oesophagitis or hiatus hernia.
  3. To find cause for haematemesis, g. oesophageal varices.
  4. Secondaries neck with unknown primary (as a part of panendoscopy).

Therapeutic

  1. Removal of a foreign body.
  2. Dilatation in case of oesophageal strictures or cardiac achalasia.
  3. Endoscopic removal of benign lesions, g. fibroma, papilloma, cysts, etc.
  4. Insertion of Souttar's or Mousseau-Barbin tube in palliative treatment of oesophageal carcinoma.
  5. Injection of oesophageal varices.

CONTRAINDICATIONS

  1. Trismus-makes the procedure technically
  2. Disease of cervical spine, e.g. cervical trauma, spondylosis, tuberculous spine, osteophytes and kyphosis. They make rigid oesophagoscopy technically difficult. Flexible fibreoptic oesophagoscopy is performed in these cases.
  3. Receding mandible.
  4. Aneurysm of aorta for fear of rupture and fatal haemorrhage.
  5. Advanced heart, liver or kidney disease may be a relative contraindication.

questions.text: Secondary haemorrage in tonsillectomy is due to
questions.solution: Secondary haemorrhage. It is a delayed complication of tonsillectomy. Usually seen between the fifth to tenth postoperative day. It is the result of sepsis and premature separation of the membrane. Usually, it is heralded by bloodstained sputum but may be profuse.

questions.text: A patient with history of road traffic accident and had a fracture in middle cranial fossa. What is the name of clinical sign shown in picture?
questions.solution:
Justification:

The clinical sign shown in the picture is called the Battle sign. It refers to the presence of ecchymosis (bruising) behind the ear and is associated with fractures involving the middle cranial fossa. The ecchymosis occurs due to the leakage of blood into the soft tissues around the mastoid process and is considered a sign of basilar skull fracture.

Other options:

  • Bryce sign: This is a bluish discoloration that is seen in the mastoid region in patients with a fracture of the temporal bone. It is not typically seen behind the ear.
  • Waters sign: This is a finding on X-ray neck AP view that is seen in patients with a fracture of the maxilla. It is not typically seen behind the ear.
  • Griesinger sign: This is a finding on X-ray neck AP view that is seen in patients with a fracture of the mandible. It is not typically seen behind the ear.

questions.text: Which of the following is not removed in radical neck dissection?
questions.solution:
Radical neck dissection is performed For metastatic cervical lymph node involvement.

It involves removal of level 1 to level 5 cervical lymph nodes.

2 muscles sternocleidomastoid and omohyoid.

2 salivary glands submandibular and sublingual.

Internal jugular vein and spinal accessory nerve.

choices.text: Electrical stimulation therapy of facial muscles

questions.text: A 46yr old came with complaint of facial palsy. On examination it was to be lower motor facial nerve palsy. On further examination there is no radiological or clinical finding. How will you treat the patient:
questions.solution:
In the case of a 46-year-old patient presenting with lower motor neuron facial nerve palsy and no identifiable radiological or clinical findings, the appropriate treatment is D) Give steroids and acyclovir.

This treatment approach is particularly relevant for conditions like Bell's palsy, where the exact cause is often idiopathic but may be associated with viral infections, such as herpes simplex virus.

Treatment Rationale

Steroids: Corticosteroids, such as prednisolone, are commonly prescribed to reduce inflammation of the facial nerve and improve recovery outcomes. They are most effective when administered early, ideally within 72 hours of symptom onset.

Acyclovir: Although the evidence for the efficacy of antivirals like acyclovir in Bell's palsy is not strong, they are often used in conjunction with steroids, especially if there is a suspicion of a viral etiology or in cases like Ramsay Hunt syndrome, where herpes zoster affects the facial nerve.

Other options provided are less appropriate in this context:

A) Facial nerve decompression: This is typically reserved for severe cases where there is evidence of significant nerve compression, which is not indicated here.

B) Acyclovir therapy alone: While antivirals may have a role, they are not the primary treatment without steroids.

C) Electrical stimulation therapy of facial muscles: This is generally not recommended in the acute phase of facial nerve palsy as it may not provide significant benefits and could potentially lead to complications.

Thus, the most suitable treatment for this patient is D) Give steroids and acyclovir.

Reference: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK549815/

questions.text: Oropharyngeal picture of a patient with Trismus, hot potato voice and dysphagia is shown in the given image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests quinsy.

Quinsy/peritonsillar abscess-

Tonsil is pushed medially and uvula is deviated to other side. This is classical feature of quinsy. There is NO outer neck swelling in Quinsy. Patient has Trismus(due to spasm of medial pterygoid muscle), odynophagia, hot potato voice.

If similar history and examination findings are there along with neck swelling close to angle of mandible, then the diagnosis is parapharyngeal abscess.

Retropharyngeal abscess is seen on the posterior pharyngeal wall and does not cause deviation of uvula.

Quiencke's disease is sudden idiopathic isolated angioedema of uvula.

questions.text: Which of the following is not premalignant:
questions.solution:
Median rhomboid glossitis is a developmental anomaly that occurs due to persistence of tuberculum impar, which fails to invaginate.

The premalignant lesions of oral cavity are leukoplakia, erythroplakia, oral submucous fibrosis, lichen planus, chronic hyperplastic candidiasis.

questions.text: Safety muscle of tongue is
questions.solution:
Genioglossus is called the safety muscle of the tongue because the two genioglossi form the bulk of the tongue and are responsible for the protusion of the tongue.

If this muscle is paralysed, the tongue will fall back into the oropharynx and obstruct the air passages.
